title: How to Make a Tooth Fairy Pouch

steps.headline: Cut a 3 by 8-inch (7.62 by 20.32-centimeter) piece of felt.
steps.description: The felt can be any color you want, except for white. You will be adding a white tooth shape on the front of the pouch. If you use white felt, the tooth won't show up!

steps.headline: Hem both of the narrow edges by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters).
steps.description: Fold both of the narrow edges down by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Pin them in place, then sew them down, as close to the inside edge as you can. You can do this by hand or on a sewing machine. You will be using these hems as tubes for the drawstrings.

steps.headline: Cut a tooth shape out of white felt.
steps.description: It needs to be about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) tall and 1½ to 2 inches (3.81 to 5.08 centimeters) wide. If you need to, draw the tooth shape first using a marker, then cut it out.

steps.headline: Pin the felt tooth to the front of the felt rectangle.
steps.description: Flip the rectangle so that the hems are on the back, and the smooth side is facing you. Pin the tooth to the top of your rectangle, about 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) down from the top, hemmed edge. Make sure that it is centered. If you drew the tooth first, make sure that you place it marker-side-down.

steps.headline: Sew tooth down using a needle and white embroidery thread.
steps.description: If you want to use the tooth as a front pocket, sew around the bottom and side edges; leave the top edge open. If you want to use it as an appliqué, sew all the way around the tooth. If you don't know how to sew, you can use hot glue or fabric glue instead. You can also sew around the tooth using your sewing machine, but it may be difficult due to its small size.

steps.headline: Fold the rectangle in half and sew up the sides.
steps.description: Fold the rectangle so that the hems are on the inside and the tooth is on the outside. Sew up the sides using a straight stitch; you can do it by hand or use a sewing machine. Do not sew the upper ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). You want the sides on the hems to remain open so that you can insert the drawstrings. Use a ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) seam allowance.

steps.headline: Thread a 14-inch (35.56-centimeter) piece of string through the left side of the bag.
steps.description:
Use a safety pin or a dull needle to pass the string through the left side of the 'front hem. Then, pull the string through the right side of the back hem so that it comes out on the left side. Tie both ends of the string together. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a6\/Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/a\/a6\/Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg\/aid8540851-v4-728px-Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Repeat this step with another 14-inch (35.56-centimeter) piece of string on the right side of the bag. You can use string, yarn, or cording. If the drawstrings are too long, trim them down.

steps.headline: Use the bag.
steps.description: Place your tooth inside the front pocket on the bag, or into the bag itself. Pull the drawstrings shut, and place the bag under your pillow. Wake up the next morning to find money in the bag.

steps.headline: Cut a 2½ by 6-inch (6.35 by 15.24 rectangle) out of felt.
steps.description: This will make the body of your pouch. It can be any color you want, except for white. You will be adding a white tooth shape on top; if the pouch is white, the tooth won't show up!

steps.headline: Fold the bottom of the felt up by 5½ inches (13.97 centimeters).
steps.description: You should have a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) gap between the two edges.

steps.headline: Sew the sides using a ¼-inch (0.64 centimeter) seam allowance.
steps.description: You can sew on a sewing machine, or you can sew it by hand. If you are sewing it by hand, consider using embroidery thread in a contrasting color for a nice, homemade touch. If you don't know how to sew, you can use fabric glue or hot glue instead. If you are sewing it by hand, you can use a simple straight stitch or a blanket stitch. If you used fabric glue, hold the edges shut with clothespins or binder clips until the glue dries.

steps.headline: Trim the seams down to ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter).
steps.description: This is not absolutely necessary, but it will help give your pouch a nicer finish. If you used a blanket stitch, don't trim the sides down, or you'll cut through the stitching.

steps.headline: Fold the flap down.
steps.description: At this point, you can topstitch along the top, folded edge to help hold the flap down. You can also simply press it flat with an iron.

steps.headline: Iron some fusible webbing to white felt.
steps.description: This will eventually make the tooth appliqué. If you don't have any fusible webbing, skip this step. Each brand of fusible webbing will be a little different, so be sure to follow the instructions on the package.

steps.headline: Cut a tooth shape out of the white felt.
steps.description: Draw a tooth shape on the back of the felt, where the webbing is. It need to be about 2 by 2 inches (5.08 by 5.08 centimeters). Cut the tooth out when you are done.

steps.headline: Iron the felt tooth to the front of the pouch, just below the flap.
steps.description: If you didn't have any fusible webbing, you glue the tooth on using fabric glue or hot glue. Avoid using too much glue, of the glue will soak through the felt.

steps.headline: Use the bag.
steps.description: Place your tooth inside the bag and fold the top flap shut. Place the bag under your pillow and go to sleep. Wake up the next morning to find money in the bag.

text:
Making a Drawstring Pouch Cut a 3 by 8-inch (7.62 by 20.32-centimeter) piece of felt. The felt can be any color you want, except for white. You will be adding a white tooth shape on the front of the pouch. If you use white felt, the tooth won't show up! Hem both of the narrow edges by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Fold both of the narrow edges down by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Pin them in place, then sew them down, as close to the inside edge as you can. You can do this by hand or on a sewing machine. You will be using these hems as tubes for the drawstrings. Cut a tooth shape out of white felt. It needs to be about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) tall and 1½ to 2 inches (3.81 to 5.08 centimeters) wide. If you need to, draw the tooth shape first using a marker, then cut it out. Pin the felt tooth to the front of the felt rectangle. Flip the rectangle so that the hems are on the back, and the smooth side is facing you. Pin the tooth to the top of your rectangle, about 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) down from the top, hemmed edge. Make sure that it is centered. If you drew the tooth first, make sure that you place it marker-side-down. Sew tooth down using a needle and white embroidery thread. If you want to use the tooth as a front pocket, sew around the bottom and side edges; leave the top edge open. If you want to use it as an appliqué, sew all the way around the tooth. If you don't know how to sew, you can use hot glue or fabric glue instead. You can also sew around the tooth using your sewing machine, but it may be difficult due to its small size. Fold the rectangle in half and sew up the sides. Fold the rectangle so that the hems are on the inside and the tooth is on the outside. Sew up the sides using a straight stitch; you can do it by hand or use a sewing machine. Do not sew the upper ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). You want the sides on the hems to remain open so that you can insert the drawstrings. Use a ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) seam allowance. Thread a 14-inch (35.56-centimeter) piece of string through the left side of the bag. Use a safety pin or a dull needle to pass the string through the left side of the 'front hem. Then, pull the string through the right side of the back hem so that it comes out on the left side. Tie both ends of the string together. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a6\/Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/a\/a6\/Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg\/aid8540851-v4-728px-Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Repeat this step with another 14-inch (35.56-centimeter) piece of string on the right side of the bag. You can use string, yarn, or cording. If the drawstrings are too long, trim them down. Use the bag. Place your tooth inside the front pocket on the bag, or into the bag itself. Pull the drawstrings shut, and place the bag under your pillow. Wake up the next morning to find money in the bag. Making a Folded Pouch Cut a 2½ by 6-inch (6.35 by 15.24 rectangle) out of felt. This will make the body of your pouch. It can be any color you want, except for white. You will be adding a white tooth shape on top; if the pouch is white, the tooth won't show up! Fold the bottom of the felt up by 5½ inches (13.97 centimeters). You should have a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) gap between the two edges. Sew the sides using a ¼-inch (0.64 centimeter) seam allowance. You can sew on a sewing machine, or you can sew it by hand. If you are sewing it by hand, consider using embroidery thread in a contrasting color for a nice, homemade touch. If you don't know how to sew, you can use fabric glue or hot glue instead. If you are sewing it by hand, you can use a simple straight stitch or a blanket stitch. If you used fabric glue, hold the edges shut with clothespins or binder clips until the glue dries. Trim the seams down to ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter). This is not absolutely necessary, but it will help give your pouch a nicer finish. If you used a blanket stitch, don't trim the sides down, or you'll cut through the stitching. Fold the flap down. At this point, you can topstitch along the top, folded edge to help hold the flap down. You can also simply press it flat with an iron. Iron some fusible webbing to white felt. This will eventually make the tooth appliqué. If you don't have any fusible webbing, skip this step. Each brand of fusible webbing will be a little different, so be sure to follow the instructions on the package. Cut a tooth shape out of the white felt. Draw a tooth shape on the back of the felt, where the webbing is. It need to be about 2 by 2 inches (5.08 by 5.08 centimeters). Cut the tooth out when you are done. Iron the felt tooth to the front of the pouch, just below the flap. If you didn't have any fusible webbing, you glue the tooth on using fabric glue or hot glue. Avoid using too much glue, of the glue will soak through the felt. Use the bag. Place your tooth inside the bag and fold the top flap shut. Place the bag under your pillow and go to sleep. Wake up the next morning to find money in the bag.
sentences: Making a Drawstring Pouch Cut a 3 by 8-inch (7.62 by 20.32-centimeter) piece of felt.
The felt can be any color you want, except for white.
You will be adding a white tooth shape on the front of the pouch.
If you use white felt, the tooth won't show up!
Hem both of the narrow edges by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters).
Fold both of the narrow edges down by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters).
Pin them in place, then sew them down, as close to the inside edge as you can.
You can do this by hand or on a sewing machine.
You will be using these hems as tubes for the drawstrings.
Cut a tooth shape out of white felt.
It needs to be about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) tall and 1½ to 2 inches (3.81 to 5.08 centimeters) wide.
If you need to, draw the tooth shape first using a marker, then cut it out.
Pin the felt tooth to the front of the felt rectangle.
Flip the rectangle so that the hems are on the back, and the smooth side is facing you.
Pin the tooth to the top of your rectangle, about 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) down from the top, hemmed edge.
Make sure that it is centered.
If you drew the tooth first, make sure that you place it marker-side-down.
Sew tooth down using a needle and white embroidery thread.
If you want to use the tooth as a front pocket, sew around the bottom and side edges; leave the top edge open.
If you want to use it as an appliqué, sew all the way around the tooth.
If you don't know how to sew, you can use hot glue or fabric glue instead.
You can also sew around the tooth using your sewing machine, but it may be difficult due to its small size.
Fold the rectangle in half and sew up the sides.
Fold the rectangle so that the hems are on the inside and the tooth is on the outside.
Sew up the sides using a straight stitch; you can do it by hand or use a sewing machine.
Do not sew the upper ½ inch (1.27 centimeters).
You want the sides on the hems to remain open so that you can insert the drawstrings.
Use a ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) seam allowance.
Thread a 14-inch (35.56-centimeter) piece of string through the left side of the bag.
Use a safety pin or a dull needle to pass the string through the left side of the 'front hem.
Then, pull the string through the right side of the back hem so that it comes out on the left side.
Tie both ends of the string together.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a6\/Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/a\/a6\/Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg\/aid8540851-v4-728px-Make-a-Tooth-Fairy-Pouch-Step-7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Repeat this step with another 14-inch (35.56-centimeter) piece of string on the right side of the bag.
You can use string, yarn, or cording.
If the drawstrings are too long, trim them down.
Use the bag.
Place your tooth inside the front pocket on the bag, or into the bag itself.
Pull the drawstrings shut, and place the bag under your pillow.
Wake up the next morning to find money in the bag.
Making a Folded Pouch Cut a 2½ by 6-inch (6.35 by 15.24 rectangle) out of felt.
This will make the body of your pouch.
It can be any color you want, except for white.
You will be adding a white tooth shape on top; if the pouch is white, the tooth won't show up!
Fold the bottom of the felt up by 5½ inches (13.97 centimeters).
You should have a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) gap between the two edges.
Sew the sides using a ¼-inch (0.64 centimeter) seam allowance.
You can sew on a sewing machine, or you can sew it by hand.
If you are sewing it by hand, consider using embroidery thread in a contrasting color for a nice, homemade touch.
If you don't know how to sew, you can use fabric glue or hot glue instead.
If you are sewing it by hand, you can use a simple straight stitch or a blanket stitch.
If you used fabric glue, hold the edges shut with clothespins or binder clips until the glue dries.
Trim the seams down to ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter).
This is not absolutely necessary, but it will help give your pouch a nicer finish.
If you used a blanket stitch, don't trim the sides down, or you'll cut through the stitching.
Fold the flap down.
At this point, you can topstitch along the top, folded edge to help hold the flap down.
You can also simply press it flat with an iron.
Iron some fusible webbing to white felt.
This will eventually make the tooth appliqué.
If you don't have any fusible webbing, skip this step.
Each brand of fusible webbing will be a little different, so be sure to follow the instructions on the package.
Cut a tooth shape out of the white felt.
Draw a tooth shape on the back of the felt, where the webbing is.
It need to be about 2 by 2 inches (5.08 by 5.08 centimeters).
Cut the tooth out when you are done.
Iron the felt tooth to the front of the pouch, just below the flap.
If you didn't have any fusible webbing, you glue the tooth on using fabric glue or hot glue.
Avoid using too much glue, of the glue will soak through the felt.
Use the bag.
Place your tooth inside the bag and fold the top flap shut.
Place the bag under your pillow and go to sleep.
Wake up the next morning to find money in the bag.
